articles.publisher: Herald Sun
articles.title: Herald Sun
articles.text:
Herald Sun
Post-pandemic work boom AUSTRALIA’S rate of unemployment has fallen to its equal lowest level in 44 years.

With further inroads into the jobless rate likely if the post-pandemic economic recovery continues, Prime Minister Scott Morrison’s goal of an unemployment score with “a three in front of it” is almost secured.
Yesterday, the Australian Bureau of Statistics announced February unemployment figures had fallen from 4.2 to 4 per cent – and the Reserve Bank believes it may plummet to ...

articles.publisher: Bill for religious freedoms
articles.title: Bill for religious freedoms
articles.text:
Bill for religious freedoms
O ne of the great privileges of representing Tangney is meeting the many communities that call Perth home.

We have vibrant, diverse communities that make life in Western Australia richer. I know this personally to be true because I’ve been welcomed by so many, and have experienced their kindness, hospitality and passion firsthand.
Last month, I joined with our local Sikh community at their temple in Canning Vale for a Sunday morning Deevan.

I also recently joined th ...

articles.publisher: PASCOE REPLY FAKE NEWS
articles.title: PASCOE REPLY FAKE NEWS
articles.text:
PASCOE REPLY FAKE NEWS
FAIR’S fair. I’ve called Bruce Pascoe a fake Aborigine pushing a fake history, so I should tell you when the old fraud finally writes some response.

Pascoe, who is still unaccountably Melbourne University’s Enterprise Professor in Indigenous Agriculture, last weekend wrote a long piece in the Nine newspapers to try to explain himself.
It isn’t actually a direct response to me, so he still doesn’t explain why genealogical records show he has not one Aboriginal ancestor. No ...

articles.publisher: Let's agree upon a date all Australians can celebrate
articles.title: Let's agree upon a date all Australians can celebrate
articles.text:
Let's agree upon a date all Australians can celebrate
Australia Day The jumbled history of dates chosen to celebrate the nation only serves to underscore that there are bound to be better options out there.

This time each year, members of the commentariat dust off their hairshirts or wait for their Southern Cross transfer tattoos to dry before assaulting the Australian public with their views on why the date for Australia Day should or should not be changed.
I confess, at the risk of having my  ...

articles.publisher: Chance for a better migration policy
articles.title: Chance for a better migration policy
articles.text:
Chance for a better migration policy
As Australia looks to open its international borders again, the federal government, quite rightly, is reassessing the size and mix of the nation's migration program. The pandemic has caused almost unprecedented disruption to the flow of people into, and out of, the country. Last financial year, a net 96,600 people left - the biggest exodus from Australia since World War I. Net overseas migration is expected this year to be minus 77,400.

This week, Treasurer  ...

articles.publisher: Private jets, parties then jail: Ghislaine, was it all worth it?
articles.title: Private jets, parties then jail: Ghislaine, was it all worth it?
articles.text:
Private jets, parties then jail: Ghislaine, was it all worth it?
It's unpleasant, but imagine being Ghislaine Maxwell right now. Despite your Oxford education and royal connections, you've just beaten out organised Eastern European gangs to become the world's highest profile sex trafficker.

You turned 60 in prison on Christmas Day. You're reviled equally by strangers and former friends. Your husband didn't show once to your trial. You're $7 million in the hole to lawyers who couldn't save your  ...

articles.title: Blacktivist outrage misplaced
articles.text:
Blacktivist outrage misplaced
FOR nearly two decades I’ve watched Indigenous activists (blactivists) go into outrage mode when there is an Indigenous death in custody.

I believe the outrage is partly due to the deliberate misrepresentation of Indigenous deaths in custody data. Another contributing factor is that blactivists will take any opportunity, like Australia Day and Coon cheese, to be “outraged” and play the victim.
Here are the facts.

A recent Australian Institute of Criminology report ...

articles.title: Shutting down discussion encourages the zealots
articles.text:

articles.text:
Balancing act
Covid 19 has highlighted our reliance on migration . But have our attitudes changed as a result. Matt Wade investigates.

Disputes over population are a staple of Australian politics. So it's no surprise there are plenty of views about what to do about immigration policy now that pandemic restrictions on international borders are being lifted.
Some urge a rapid catch-up. A leaked briefing prepared by bureaucrats for new NSW Premier Dominic Perrottet suggested he push for "an aggres ...

For Jane Carroll, moving overseas to work was a rite of passage that was always part of her plan.
"I watched other people go overseas and I thought: 'Once I'm a chartered accountant, I'd love to go live and work overseas.' I'd worked f ...

articles.text:

THE announcement by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority to tighten the requirements for home loans means getting a mortgage will be more difficult – particularly for some investors and new-home buyers.

While there are prudent reasons for this move (e.g. so “borrowers are well equipped to service their debts under a range of scenarios”, such as runaway house prices and potentially rising interest rates), it takes place within the accelerating ...

articles.publisher: Herald Sun
articles.title: Herald Sun
articles.text:
Herald Sun
Home dream can be saved THE great Aussie dream – surely it cannot be lost for this and future generations of young people.

Sadly, if superheated property prices and stagnant wages keep going the way they are, and interest rates inch higher, the only options for many will be reliance on the Bank of Mum and Dad, inheritances or – at a stretch – unit living.
On one measure of price to income, Melbourne now has the fifth-least affordable housing in the world. The median house price is 12 ...

articles.publisher: JOB HOPPERS CHASE PAY BUMPS
articles.title: JOB HOPPERS CHASE PAY BUMPS
articles.text:
JOB HOPPERS CHASE PAY BUMPS
Employment The competition to recruit skilled workers and keep them happy could force a rise in real wages as early as this year, writes Julie Hare.

Australians are living in the best labour market in 50 years. By the end of last year, there were 13,242,000 Australians in paid work, nearly 3 per cent higher than a year earlier. A record 366,100 jobs were added in November alone, eclipsing forecasts by about 160,000.
"The last time we had an unemployment rate below 4  ...

articles.publisher: Trade-off a recipe for fiscal anxiety
articles.title: Trade-off a recipe for fiscal anxiety
articles.text:
Trade-off a recipe for fiscal anxiety
Another year, another national wage case.

Notwithstanding lots of fancy charts and tables, the argument always boils down to the trade-off between meeting workers’ needs and the capacity of firms to afford higher wages.
This argument is undertaken in the context of an uncertain macroeconomic environment. This time, both the Australian and global macroeconomic outlooks are deteriorating.

Inflation is increasing, energy prices are skyrocketing, the stockmark ...

articles.publisher: Left-Lib warrior for Labor
articles.title: Left-Lib warrior for Labor
articles.text:
Left-Lib warrior for Labor
WHO needs Labor, when the Liberals have their own Matt Kean to blow up their election campaign?

Kean, the NSW Treasurer, on Tuesday gave Labor its biggest free kick of the campaign by smearing one of the Liberals’ own candidates, making false claims and calling her “not fit for office”.
Truly, Kean is one of those Left-wing Liberals who have made their party a comfort to its enemies and an embarrassment to its friends.

Kean’s target was Katherine Deves, who is trying ...

THE fate of the Morrison government now rests in the hands of Anthony Albanese and how he chooses to respond to its plan to turbocharge immigration in the next financial year.

On Thursday, Josh Frydenberg will release the government’s Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook, an update to its budget forecasts that will show the economy is set to roar back to life as the pandemic disappears in the rear-view mirror.
Well that’s the Treasury’s view anyway. These things are o ...

articles.text:
THE CONTENDERS
Wiradjuri woman Yvonne Weldon is the first Indigenous Australian to run for lord mayor in the 179-year history of the City of Sydney council. She was endorsed by former councillor Kerryn Phelps. Weldon has spent 20 years working and volunteering in roles linked to education, land rights, health, youth justice and domestic violence.

Angela Vithoulkas from the Small Business Party was elected to council as an independent in 2012. Her long-time business, Vivo Cafe, suffered during c ...

articles.publisher: Good and bad news for government in budget update
articles.title: Good and bad news for government in budget update
articles.text:
Good and bad news for government in budget update
There are mid-year budget updates and then there are mid-year budget updates that land just months before a federal election. For a government behind in the polls and eager to make managing the economy its central election pitch, it's an opportune time to play up the good news and downplay the bad. There is a good amount of both.

Headlining the good news is the unemployment figures. An intractable problem of previous recessions, the jobs market  ...

articles.title: TWISTED HATE CLAIM IS SICK
articles.text:
TWISTED HATE CLAIM IS SICK
NOT even this pandemic will stop our professional race baiters from spreading their poison. Dear God, let them please, finally, shut up.

Last week, Greens Senator Lidia Thorpe (left) complained that sending our soldiers to help the vaccine rollout in Aboriginal communities like Wilcannia was proof of “systemic racism”. Which Aborigines would trust this “militarised response”?
Yet this week Thorpe, who identifies as Aboriginal, complained that one Aborigine in Wilcanni ...

articles.publisher: For children's sake, reopen schools
articles.title: For children's sake, reopen schools
articles.text:
For children's sake, reopen schools
A group of notable Australians have written an open letter to state and federal governments setting out why it is safe to open schools.

In the third year of the COVID-19 pandemic, we now have evidence that it is safe to allow schools to be open for face-to-face learning.
The national cabinet commitment to re-open schools is at risk, however, and needs to be reaffirmed by every jurisdiction, with measures taken to reassure Australian families that schools are  ...

articles.text:

Macfarlane's thesis is that the original sin of the current housing boom - generous tax incentives including negative gearing and capital gains tax discounts - have made property  ...

articles.title: Take the time to write a proper religious bill
articles.text:
Take the time to write a proper religious bill
The debate over the federal government's religious discrimination bill may have been put on hold but it has exposed deep fissures in Australian society which will take time and careful thought to resolve.

While there is broad agreement that religion deserves the same protection from discrimination as sex, race and gender it is also clear there must be restrictions on expressions of religious belief which conflict with the standards of tolerance tha ...

articles.publisher: Albo's got it right on aged care
articles.title: Albo's got it right on aged care
articles.text:
Albo's got it right on aged care
Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese's focus on improving the quality of life in Australia's aged care facilities could well be the issue that carries him over the line to victory in the federal election.

His five-point plan aims to "stop the neglect and put security, dignity, quality and humanity back into aged care".
The two prongs at the forefront of Albo's policy initiative are employing registered nurses 24 hours a day, and paying decent wages.

He has tapped ...

articles.publisher: A tax solution to aged care crisis
articles.title: A tax solution to aged care crisis
articles.text:
A tax solution to aged care crisis
Funding shortfall Neither Labor nor the Coalition has been honest about paying for aged care. Scrapping superannuation tax perks for the rich kills two birds with one stone.

I'm sure I wasn't the only policy wonk with their eyebrows raised at the conclusion of Opposition Leader Anthony Albanese's budget reply speech last week.
Of course, I had no issues with the five-point plan he laid out to address problems in aged care, such as nursing coverage and food qua ...

articles.publisher: The Advertiser Boost house supply to curb homelessness
articles.title: The Advertiser Boost house supply to curb homelessness
articles.text:
The Advertiser Boost house supply to curb homelessness
SOMETHING is desperately wrong in a modern and relatively prosperous country like Australia when people have to live in tents because they cannot find a house to rent.

Alarmingly, this is a nationwide issue that is strikingly epitomised by Tracy and Allen Short, who have spent more than two months camped in a Mannum reserve, on the banks of the River Murray.
They are, sadly, not alone in their unfortunate plight. Rental properties have beco ...

articles.publisher: Reopening borders will help economy roar back
articles.title: Reopening borders will help economy roar back
articles.text:
Reopening borders will help economy roar back
A timely program of booster jabs will maintain recovery momentum

Australia’s double-dose vaccination rate moved past 85 per cent on Sunday, as Scott Morrison and Josh Frydenberg were preparing to maximise the economic benefits of the final phase of the national reopening plan. More than 200,000 visa holders will be allowed into the nation, including students, economic migrants and refugees. In meetings last week with businesses from almost every sec ...

articles.title: Today is a day for truth telling, not just celebrations
articles.text:
Today is a day for truth telling, not just celebrations
In the lead-up to today's Australia Day celebrations, many churches across the country held a Day of Mourning service, to reflect upon and lament the invasion and colonisation of this nation's First Peoples.

Certainly the church I belong to, the Uniting Church, has strongly encouraged their congregations to hold such services, to stand together with and listen to the wisdom of First Nations people in their struggle for justice.
But in prac ...

articles.publisher: Education ought to be key plank of campaign
articles.title: Education ought to be key plank of campaign
articles.text:
Education ought to be key plank of campaign
GIVEN that early voting in the federal election started on Monday, the ALP’s big ticket education announcements have come very late in the game.

The ALP has pledged to pay a bonus of $10,000 per year to 5000 students with an ATAR of 80 or more to incentivise them to go into teaching.
This announcement will be welcomed by some, but arguably the bigger challenge is paying them enough once they become teachers to keep them in teaching.

There’s the natio ...

articles.text:

Labor leader Anthony Albanese is preparing to parachute an eastern suburbs-located "celebrity" candidate into the marginal Labor-held seat of Parramatta, angering local branch members and even drawing cries of structural racism.

Andrew Charlton, a former economics adviser to Kevin Rudd and Accenture managing director who lives in Sydney's ritzy Bellevue Hill, is Mr Albanese's pick for the multicu ...

articles.text:
Labor backs stage three tax cuts and aspiration not envy
The AFR View

Labor's welcome decision to leave Josh Frydenberg's stage three tax cuts in place is good news for national prosperity and confirms the 2019 federal election lesson that the politics of envy has limited appeal in aspirational Australia. After all, this will leave the sort of personal income tax scales that Paul Keating and Kevin Rudd have backed in the past.
As political editor Phillip Coorey revealed yesterday, Labor's leadi ...

articles.publisher: Aged care promise not enough
articles.title: Aged care promise not enough
articles.text:
Aged care promise not enough
Anthony Albanese should be congratulated for putting aged care reform as a central platform of Labor's response to the federal budget.

The initiatives put forward are positive, welcomed and necessary, however the overall strategy does not address the fundamental failures in the age care sector. What we need and our older citizens and their families deserve is an action plan for the future. Labor's aged care package has five parts, each part with substantial instant  ...

articles.publisher: Absurd racism claims only weaken the cause
articles.title: Absurd racism claims only weaken the cause
articles.text:
Absurd racism claims only weaken the cause
EARLIER this month, Sydney’s Daily Telegraph published an article on what role an Aboriginal advisory body may have on the Australian curriculum.

The article referred to an Aboriginal Australian who has a PhD in mathematics, Dr Chris Matthews, stating “he has made the case that the teaching of maths is systematically racist”.
Indeed, in an academic article in 2007, Dr Matthews wrote that “mathematics education devalues Indigenous culture”.

I admire th ...

articles.title: True cost of lockdowns emerging
articles.text:

The loss of social freedoms is taking a heavy toll on mental health
The worst fears about the hidden cost of the pandemic response on mental health and youth crisis are being realised. Hospital admissions of youths who have self-harmed are rising alongside the escalating financial cost from tight restrictions on social contact. All of these factors must be taken into consideration as political leaders and parents weigh the difficult decisions on extending vaccinat ...

articles.publisher: Tax cuts due, but we need to talk about offsets
articles.title: Tax cuts due, but we need to talk about offsets
articles.text:
Tax cuts due, but we need to talk about offsets
There is a strong chance next year's federal election campaign will include a promise from the Coalition of further tax cuts for middle and low-income earners.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison, while refusing to be drawn on whether he will extend for another year the so-called "Lamington" tax offset, worth $1080 in the pockets of low and middle-income earners come tax time, responds that tax cuts are "always our approach".

articles.title: Jobless rate falls to near 50-year-low, fuelling rates rise expectations
articles.text:
Jobless rate falls to near 50-year-low, fuelling rates rise expectations
Australia's tight labour market could be nearing saturation point with unemployment at near 50-year lows, but is expected to tighten further in coming months, driving wages growth and increasing pressure on the Reserve Bank to raise interest rates after the federal election in May.

Australian Bureau of Statistics data released on Thursday showed unemployment fell slightly but remained at 4 per cent in March due to rounding ...

articles.title: Good day to take stock of how far nation has come
articles.text:
Good day to take stock of how far nation has come
Our land’s modern and ancient history are both worth celebrating

The founding of modern Australia 234 years ago when 1400 people, more than half of them convicts, arrived in Port Jackson on 11 boats after eight treacherous, cramped months at sea from Portsmouth in southern England was an extraordinary start for any nation. At the end of the journey, as Captain Arthur Phillip later wrote: “We had the satisfaction of finding the finest harbour in  ...

articles.publisher: Let’s keep this bill shelved
articles.title: Let’s keep this bill shelved
articles.text:
Let’s keep this bill shelved
The religious discrimination bill has been trying to find a solution to a problem that doesn’t exist, writes Joe Hildebrand

BAD policies are like Frankenstein’s monster. Anybody watching while they are cobbled together can see it’s going to end in disaster but it’s only after they are brought to life that those who made them finally realise the abomination they’ve created.
The federal government’s religious discrimination bill is just such a beast. Its only redeemin ...

articles.publisher: Kids must be chief priority
articles.title: Kids must be chief priority
articles.text:
Kids must be chief priority
VICTORIA’S chief psychiatrist has belatedly addressed the public after pressure from media and leading mental health experts.

But all we got were empty platitudes and mealy-mouthed “captain obvious” advice. One could be forgiven for thinking Neil Coventry was in a witness protection program as Victorians endured one of the harshest and longest lockdowns anywhere in the world.
What we need to know is what role, if any, has the chief psychiatrist played in advising Dan ...

articles.publisher: Too quick to press cancel on new human rights chief
articles.title: Too quick to press cancel on new human rights chief
articles.text:
Too quick to press cancel on new human rights chief
Even before starting in the role, the new human rights commissioner has contributed significantly to the human rights discussion in Australia. The appointment of Lorraine Finlay has horrified sections of the activist commentariat. From Crikey to ABC radio, Finlay's supposed sins were listed and repeated: she has spoken against affirmative consent, the Uluru Statement from the Heart and section 18C of the Racial Discrimination Act. She has even  ...

articles.publisher: Gender-balanced cabinet a vital moment for women's leadership
articles.title: Gender-balanced cabinet a vital moment for women's leadership
articles.text:
Gender-balanced cabinet a vital moment for women's leadership
Equality Women were a decisive voice in this federal election, yet in the corporate world, progress in elevating them appears to have stalled.

Last month we witnessed record numbers of women sworn into the highest decision-making table in our land. At Chief Executive Women our mission is to enable women leaders, so we warmly welcome this historic moment - a gender-balanced federal cabinet marks an important moment for women's leaders ...

articles.publisher: STREWTH

articles.text:
STREWTH
Satan’s stamp duty Here’s an unlikely alliance – Amanda Stoker and BrotherSamael Demo-Gorgon (also known as LGBTI activist and former Sex Party candidate Robin Bristow). The notorious Noosa Temple of Satan sat down with the LNP senator in Brisbane on Monday afternoon for a tete-a-tete about religious freedoms. After the faithful expressed frustration with Christian Porter’s failure to pass the Religious Discrimination Bill – a 2019 election promise by Prime Minister Scott Morrison – the  ...

articles.publisher: Knives out for an unremarkable reform
articles.title: Knives out for an unremarkable reform
articles.text:
Knives out for an unremarkable reform
Next week, the federal government is expected to introduce its long-awaited Religious Discrimination Bill that will make it unlawful to discriminate against religious Australians. The largely unremarkable bill will extend protection to religious belief that attributes such race and sexuality have enjoyed for decades.

If enacted, it will extend protection to citizens of NSW and South Australia who now legally can be refused service, fired or rejected for job ...

articles.publisher: Trans lifter deserves her spot at the Games
articles.title: Trans lifter deserves her spot at the Games
articles.text:
Trans lifter deserves her spot at the Games
TRANSGENDER athletes such as Laurel Hubbard should be welcomed as Olympic competitors as long as they meet the rules.

The IOC is committed to inclusion and this should include female athletes who started life as males. Like many other local and international organisations, the IOC no longer views gender in simple biological terms.
Since 2015, an athlete born male can compete in the Olympics as a female without sex reassignment surgery as long as she m ...

articles.publisher: The Advertiser Still a long way to go for older citizens
articles.title: The Advertiser Still a long way to go for older citizens
articles.text:
The Advertiser Still a long way to go for older citizens
IT’S been said many times before, but it’s no less true for that. A good marker for the health of any society is how it treats and cares for its most vulnerable citizens.

The young, the sick, the disabled and the aged to name but a few. How Australia treats its older citizens has garnered a great deal of attention in recent years. The Aged Care Royal Commission released its final report this year after a lengthy investigation process whic ...

articles.publisher: The figures say wages are static. Here's why they're wrong
articles.title: The figures say wages are static. Here's why they're wrong
articles.text:
The figures say wages are static. Here's why they're wrong
Have you heard about the latest wage figures? I hope not. They're meaningless.

What the widely quoted measure of average weekly earnings purports to show is that wages grew a mere 0.1 per cent over the year to May. It's not true. It's not what happened. For most of us, wages grew by much more.
That's not to say wage growth has been high - the best estimate is that private sector wages have climbed 1.9 per cent over the past year and pub ...

articles.publisher: Building to beat crisis
articles.title: Building to beat crisis
articles.text:
Building to beat crisis
There is only one way to defeat Australia’s long-lasting housing shortage, and that’s to get on the tools

Australia is in the grip of a serious housing ­crisis that won’t be solved by the home ownership incentives being offered during this federal election campaign.
Regardless of who wins the 2022 election on May 21, the only way for us to get out of this crisis is to build more than 30,000 units of social and affordable housing each year for the next 10 years.

This wil ...

articles.publisher: No home, no kids, and nothing left to lose
articles.title: No home, no kids, and nothing left to lose
articles.text:
No home, no kids, and nothing left to lose
Across the Western world wealth inequality is being usurped by housing inequality as the most reliable indicator of disparity in society. For many people of my generation – especially those who wish to start or expand their families – housing affordability is likely to become the single most important issue for them in federal and state elections.

According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, residential property prices surged 23.7 per cent last ye ...

articles.publisher: Skills not on the menu
articles.title: Skills not on the menu
articles.text:
Skills not on the menu
The Australian hospitality and tourism industries were among the first to be affected by the Covid pandemic and the way things are shaping up they will be certainly among the last to recover This is a crisis! Australia’s tourism and hospitality sectors are once again under siege. After almost two years of devastation, our industry is facing further long-term pain due to the nationwide skills shortage.

Before the Omicron outbreak began crippling businesses, our industry wa ...

articles.publisher: Time to regulate state's hidden shame
articles.title: Time to regulate state's hidden shame
articles.text:
Time to regulate state's hidden shame
Beneath the recent revelations by The Age and disturbing stories coming from the Royal Commission into Aged Care lies an industry largely unregulated and almost totally hidden to most Victorians: the supported residential services.

For more than 40 years, welfare advocates have despaired at the plight of the elderly, frail and disabled residents living in these supported residential services.
While there are no doubt some pension-only supported residential  ...

articles.publisher: POSTSCRIPT
articles.title: POSTSCRIPT
articles.text:
POSTSCRIPT
"I do not think in over 40 years of reading letters I have been more upset and full of rage than when reading the account of a young nurse's working day in an aged care home," wrote Wendy Atkins of Cooks Hill.

Many responded similarly about the letter describing the young nurse's long shifts, with lack of training and support. The letter, like others published this week, was an insight into how dire the COVID situation is for many, with personal stories "cutting to the terrible heart ...

articles.publisher: Australia Day evolution
articles.title: Australia Day evolution
articles.text:
Australia Day evolution
The AFR View

'Change the date" activism has not built popular momentum for moving Australia's national day from January 26. Between two-thirds and three-quarters of Australians support the current date. But that doesn't rule out rethinking how Australia Day is celebrated. Modern Australia is one of the most peaceful, prosperous and successful societies on earth. The events of January 26, 1788, reflect the achievement of Enlightenment liberalism that the British transport ...

articles.publisher: Scrap LMITO and replace the cash splash with real tax reform
articles.title: Scrap LMITO and replace the cash splash with real tax reform
articles.text:

Budget The Treasurer should include an additional tax cut in the stage 3 package instead of extending the poorly designed rebate for a third time.

One problem for the 2022-23 federal budget is the fate of the $8 billion low- and middle-income tax offset (LMITO) and its relationship with economic management, deficit reduction and tax reform.
Treasurer Josh Frydenberg emphasises that the offset, introduced in its current form in 2019-20 ...

articles.publisher: Christian ban smacks of hubris
articles.title: Christian ban smacks of hubris
articles.text:
Christian ban smacks of hubris
The McGowan government in Western Australia has pushed the boundaries of cancel culture to a new and worrying level by banning a Christian organisation from hiring public facilities because its views do not align with those of WA Labor. The policies used to stop the Australian Christian Lobby from booking Perth Concert Hall and the Albany Entertainment Centre may well contravene anti-discrimination laws. But it is, above all, an insidious form of censorship that wo ...

articles.publisher: After the wedging and sledging, ugly truths persevere
articles.title: After the wedging and sledging, ugly truths persevere
articles.text:
After the wedging and sledging, ugly truths persevere
Comment

At the risk of relying on tired cultural references, it was Dumbledore who once told Harry Potter: "It's our choices, Harry, that show what we truly are, far more than our abilities."
For a long time now we have been told by advocates of the religious discrimination bill that, in this increasingly secular world, it was vital to give some extra legal protection to people of faith to ensure they were not victims of prejudice or vilific ...

articles.publisher: Labor set to promote women to key roles in cabinet
articles.title: Labor set to promote women to key roles in cabinet
articles.text:
Labor set to promote women to key roles in cabinet
Women will be promoted to key roles across the federal government in a series of Labor factional meetings on Monday that are expected to confirm Clare O'Neil from Victoria and Jenny McAllister from NSW as likely cabinet ministers.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is waiting on the factions to decide who enters the cabinet before he names people to posts including home affairs and environment so the full ministry can be sworn in at Government Hou ...

articles.publisher: Is our home ownership dream a thing of the past?
articles.title: Is our home ownership dream a thing of the past?
articles.text:
Is our home ownership dream a thing of the past?
Property affordability Australia is at risk of losing a generation of home owners. The political and economic consequences will be quite profound.

On January 1, 1901, Australia's six colonies (OK, Western Australia was late to the party) came together to form the Australian Commonwealth.
There were many reasons driving disparate parts of this continent together. One was the promise of an Australian dream centred on home ownership.

The significan ...

articles.publisher: Sudden interest in mental health suspect
articles.title: Sudden interest in mental health suspect
articles.text:
Sudden interest in mental health suspect
The frequent appearance of chief health officers alongside political leaders throughout the pandemic has run the danger that the roles of such trusted public officials may transition from advisory to political.

Alongside, there has always been the risk of politicians selectively using health "advice" to support political decisions. With particular reference to mental health, we are now witnessing these risks.
Most notably, the Premier of NSW has highligh ...

articles.publisher: Land cost drives house price blues
articles.title: Land cost drives house price blues
articles.text:
Land cost drives house price blues
Home ownership We are reaping the effects of two generations of failure by state and local governments to wean themselves off land charges.

Australia has built a successful liberal democracy on the back of sound economic management, absence of a strict class structure and equality of opportunity.
Egalitarianism and a sense of a fair go coupled with high levels of home ownership have underpinned social cohesion and allowed communities to flourish.

Nonetheless, ...

articles.publisher: For a better class of teacher, invest in smarter training
articles.title: For a better class of teacher, invest in smarter training
articles.text:
For a better class of teacher, invest in smarter training
It is 10 years this week since the release of David Gonski’s landmark report into school funding. The report and its recommendations have cast a decade-long shadow over education policy and politics. Sadly, Australia’s education system is no better off, with slumping student results and little regard for how funding is spent.

A milestone of the Gillard government, Gonski’s inquiry provided the most substantial reform to school funding si ...

articles.publisher: Why the government's Religious Discrimination Bill is a bad outcome for women
articles.title: Why the government's Religious Discrimination Bill is a bad outcome for women
articles.text:
Why the government's Religious Discrimination Bill is a bad outcome for women
It was a relief this year to see the federal government take steps towards implementing the two excellent reports on women's workplace safety by the Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Repect@Work and Set the Standard. Both tackle the cultural barriers to women's workforce engagement in the form of harassment and discrimination.

At the same time, it's great to hear that the federal government is interested in legislating ...

articles.publisher: Words that fail to add up
articles.title: Words that fail to add up
articles.text:
Words that fail to add up
In his new book on Scott Morrison, former political adviser Sean Kelly examines the difficulty in working out what the PM means.

In the fifth week of his prime ministership, Scott Morrison posted a tweet accompanied by a picture of two blue thongs. The thongs were painted with white stars and the Union Jack to represent the Australian flag. They were propped upright in sand, the ocean behind them. The tweet read:
Indulgent self-loathing doesn't make Australia stronger. ...

articles.publisher: Legislating on social media is no remedy for alienation
articles.title: Legislating on social media is no remedy for alienation
articles.text:
Legislating on social media is no remedy for alienation
It’s clear that social media does great damage to the minds and psychological wellbeing of young people. Perhaps legislation can do something to address this, but to try to do so may be to embrace “safetyism” and ignore root causes. To fix the problem of psychological stress exacerbated by social media requires an understanding of why so many young people pour endless hours of their lives into social media, aside from the obvious explanatio ...

articles.publisher: Why our seniors must be a priority
articles.title: Why our seniors must be a priority
articles.text:
Why our seniors must be a priority
LABOR’S attempt to avoid scrutiny in this election campaign is most clearly evident in its latest ploy to convince voters it has the solutions to aged care.

More than a year after the Royal Commission into Aged Care Quality and Safety, the Opposition leader is either announcing policies the government is already implementing or, of greater concern, is deliberately going against the recommendations, running the risk of shutting down major aged care homes and le ...

articles.publisher: Pearl-clutchers keep the Liberals out of step
articles.title: Pearl-clutchers keep the Liberals out of step
articles.text:
Pearl-clutchers keep the Liberals out of step
By all accounts, Allegra Spender was the Ascham head girl it was difficult to dislike.

At the wealthy Sydney school, equidistant from two institutions of eastern suburbs social life, Joh Bailey hairdressers and the Cruising Yacht Club of Australia, the daughter of Carla Zampatti, AC, and John Spender, QC, was friendly, funny and modest.
As Spender now threatens a Coalition seat, Wentworth, and possibly the government's majority, on a climate-policy  ...

articles.publisher: The Advertiser Act on aged care
articles.title: The Advertiser Act on aged care
articles.text:
The Advertiser Act on aged care
IT seems the stream of horror stories emanating from our aged-care facilities is never ending.

Today, The Advertiser reveals that elderly residents are being left lying in urine or breaking bones in falls because there simply are not enough staff members to take care of them.
The news comes only days after we broke the news that 15 aged-care homes in SA are failing to meet national standards.

It also follows a Royal Commission into Aged Care and Quality Safety w ...

articles.publisher: United we can celebrate diversity
articles.title: United we can celebrate diversity
articles.text:
United we can celebrate diversity
Divisive agendas often don’t know where they are heading Long-running efforts to delegitimise Australia Day as a celebration of nationhood have become systemic, with news that major companies are planning to allow employees to work on January 26 and take another day off that better suits their beliefs or world view. A flexible approach to working hours is to be applauded. But behind the incrementalist diminution of what has been a reason for shared community cel ...

articles.publisher: A new era and better public holiday
articles.title: A new era and better public holiday
articles.text:
A new era and better public holiday
This is the46th annual NAIDOC Week, an annual occasion of remembrance and resistance that has evolved into a vibrant national celebration of our Communities, Cultures and Country, alongside our excellence and collective resilience and survival as custodians of the world's oldest continuous living cultures.

As the week nears its 50th birthday, it is surely time to recognise a more positive national day to celebrate and honour our First Peoples, for all Austral ...

articles.publisher: Back to religious discrimination basics
articles.title: Back to religious discrimination basics
articles.text:
Back to religious discrimination basics
The proposed Religious Discrimination Act has raised more questions and potential problems than it has provided solutions. It was meant to give solutions and offer protection.

As an Islamic organisation, we at the Forum on Australia's Islamic Relations have a responsibility to our constituents to ensure that discrimination based on religion against any Australian is eradicated from our society, let alone against Australians of the Islamic faith.
We have w ...

articles.publisher: No type of aggression is OK in the workplace
articles.title: No type of aggression is OK in the workplace
articles.text:
No type of aggression is OK in the workplace
WHEN we talk about workplace gendered violence, it’s the clear-cut examples people tend to think of first. Acts of violence such as a fist through a wall or assault are easy to condemn (and rightly so).

But the so-called “harmless” comments? The “joke” you accidentally overhear in the lunch room? The look that lingers a little too long? Or the unofficial meetings that somehow always happen when you’re not around? These things can be harder to call ou ...

articles.publisher: Switching focus is the way to national unity
articles.title: Switching focus is the way to national unity
articles.text:
Switching focus is the way to national unity
TO some Australians, January 26, Australia Day, is a day of pride, nationhood and achievement.

However, to First Nations peoples, January 26 is a day of mourning, trauma and protest. Unfortunately, our national day is underpinned by this stark division.
Each Australia Day is an opportunity for us, as individuals and as a society, to be informed, sensitive and empathetic.

Working towards becoming better allies and standing in solidarity with Aborigin ...

articles.publisher: ‘Don't take chances': Employers argue for ‘modest' rise in minimum wage
articles.title: ‘Don't take chances': Employers argue for ‘modest' rise in minimum wage
articles.text:
‘Don't take chances': Employers argue for ‘modest' rise in minimum wage
Employers are calling for a 2 per cent increase in the minimum wage in a move that would deliver a cut in real incomes for millions of workers already facing cost-of-living pressures.

Arguing for the "modest" pay increase, Australian Industry Group chief executive Innes Willox urged the industrial umpire "not to take chances" as the economy recovered from the coronavirus pandemic, noting ongoing supply chain disruptions and ...

articles.publisher: Tackling education malaise crucial to future prosperity
articles.title: Tackling education malaise crucial to future prosperity
articles.text:

articles.publisher: Skills and age profile of migrants just as important as numbers
articles.title: Skills and age profile of migrants just as important as numbers
articles.text:
Skills and age profile of migrants just as important as numbers
Policy Permanent skilled migration should be weighted towards younger migrants who will make a much bigger contribution to Australian society.

Public debate about migration policy in Australia tends to swirl around just one thing: picking a number.
As our borders reopen, debate is again raging about the size of Australia's annual migrant intake. It may even turn out to be a big election issue.

But how many migrants is just one par ...

articles.publisher: The Advertiser Time to end aged care fees gouging
articles.title: The Advertiser Time to end aged care fees gouging
articles.text:
The Advertiser Time to end aged care fees gouging
THE revelation that some aged care providers are gouging almost $1000 a fortnight in fees out of vulnerable pensioners is nothing short of disgraceful.

Clearly, if some providers are charging two thirds more than others for providing the same levels of care for vulnerable customers, the industry is ripe for reform.
Put simply, the less a pensioner loses in fees from their allocated package, the more cash is available for their care and improving ...

articles.publisher: For-profit industry is broken, must be fixed
articles.title: For-profit industry is broken, must be fixed
articles.text:
For-profit industry is broken, must be fixed
Aged Care

More money thrown at aged care will not fix the problems, any more than it did in education ("Albanese's $2.5b vow for fairer aged care", April 1).
While aged care remains privatised, greedy companies will find ways around restrictions. Turning the elderly into cash cows and herding them into ghettos will always end in exploitation by companies with no experience in, or aptitude for, caring.

You only need to look at the boards the provider ...

articles.publisher: Many can't observe 'national' day
articles.title: Many can't observe 'national' day
articles.text:
Many can't observe 'national' day
Marking January 26 can only be a 'celebration' of the beginning of white takeover, not the founding of a nation.

While most nations use their national day to celebrate their identity and/or birth, Australia is approaching yet another Australia Day with continued human confusion and muddle about both. Geographically we are certain what Australia is. Humanly we are not.
Every Australia Day reminds us of the two big unresolved matters of Australian identification: ...

articles.publisher: Herald Sun
articles.title: Herald Sun
articles.text:
Herald Sun
Care for aged is fundamental ANY society is judged on how it looks after its most vulnerable but in aged care Australia has been failing too often in providing uniform quality care and protection.

When things go wrong, respect and dignity are eroded, if substandard service is delivered or neglect endured, the impact on our most vulnerable citizens is horrendous, often cruel and clearly intolerable.
Quality aged care for all who need it is a fundamental right. Having worked and paid t ...

articles.publisher: The kids are not all white: getting skin in power games
articles.title: The kids are not all white: getting skin in power games
articles.text:
The kids are not all white: getting skin in power games
A Labor preselection battle sparked an examination of Parliament, which 'looks like it's stuck in the White Australia era', writes Katina Curtis.

'Stale, pale and male" has become a shorthand for the lack of diversity of all kinds across society's institutions. Parliament has not escaped its accusations and even federal politicians have levelled the tag at it.
Labor frequently pats itself on the back for achieving near-gender parity

in it ...
